title: How to Add Borders in Illustrator

steps.title: Open Illustrator.
steps.content: Open Illustrator. Its app icon resembles an orange "Ai" on a dark background.

steps.title: Open your Illustrator project.
steps.content: Open your Illustrator project. Click Open... , then select an existing project. If you don't have an existing project, you can simply select a photo to get started. On some versions of Illustrator, you may first have to click File before selecting Open... in the drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click the "Typography" drop-down box.
steps.content: Click the "Typography" drop-down box. It's in the upper-right side of the page. A drop-down menu will appear. This box may also say "Start". If this box says "Essentials" in it, skip this step and the next one.

steps.title: Click Essentials.
steps.content: Click Essentials . This is near the top of the drop-down menu.

steps.title: Select your content.
steps.content: Select your content. Click the photo, text, or other element on the page that you want to outline.

steps.title: Click the Window tab.
steps.content: Click the Window tab. It's at the top of the window (Windows) or the screen (Mac). A drop-down menu will appear.

steps.title: Click Appearance.
steps.content: Click Appearance . You'll find this near the top of the drop-down menu. The Appearance mini-window will open near your project.

steps.title: Click ☰.
steps.content: Click ☰ . It's in the top-right corner of the Appearance window. This will prompt a drop-down menu. The icon here actually has four horizontal lines instead of three.

steps.title: Click Add New Stroke.
steps.content: Click Add New Stroke . It's in the drop-down menu. The Stroke menu will open.

steps.title: Double-click the "Stroke" icon.
steps.content: Double-click the "Stroke" icon. It's a box wrapped around a smaller box in the lower-left corner of the window. This will open the Stroke Color window. [1] X Research source You should see a white box with a red slash through it either behind or in front of the "Stroke" icon.

steps.title: Select a color.
steps.content: Select a color. Click and drag up or down the color bar on the right side of the window to change the overall color, then click a section on the gradient to select a specific iteration of that color. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . It's in the top-right corner of the Stroke Color window.

steps.title: Click the Effect tab.
steps.content: Click the Effect tab. This is at the top of the window or screen. Doing so prompts a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Select Path.
steps.content: Select Path . It's near the top of the Effect drop-down menu. A pop-out window will appear next to the Path option.

steps.title: Click Outline Object.
steps.content: Click Outline Object . You'll see this in the pop-out window. A border will appear around your content.

steps.title: Edit your border's thickness.
steps.content: Edit your border's thickness. In the Appearance window, you'll see a numbered box to the right of the "Stroke" heading. Clicking the upward-facing arrow to the left of this number will increase your border's thickness, while clicking the downward-facing arrow will decrease the thickness.

steps.title: Save your changes.
steps.content: Save your changes. Click File , then click Save in the drop-down menu to save your changes to your project. [3] X Research source You can also click Save As if you want to save this project separately, or if it's a new project. You'll then be prompted to enter a name and choose a save location.
